awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Microscale Selective Laser Sintering Process
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to enable fabrication of high-density, high-aspect-ratio, freeform 3-dimentional (3D_ microscale interconnect structures at rates up to three times faster than existing technologies. This new commercial capability may have far-reaching implications due to the significant demand for new advanced packaging technologies for integrated circuits. The microscale, selective, laser sintering system has the potential to lower the cost of consumer and business facing products such as cloud web services and mobile computing while enabling new high-performance embedded applications such as self-driving vehicle technology, radiation-hard and high-acceleration sensing, and internet-connected medical devices. This technology may also potentially enable new packaging architectures not possible using current state-of-the-art fabrication techniques, increasing the design freedom of integrated circuit architects and enabling new technologies and applications.

This I-Corps project further develops a microscale selective sintering process.  In this process a layer of nanoparticle ink is coated using a slot-die coater and shuttled to the optical subsystem using a long-range custom air-bearing stage. There, a laser is focused through a digital micromirror device to sinter the nanoparticles into the desired pattern. After the first layer is sintered, the air-bearing stage translates the substrate back under the coater for the deposition of the next layer. The process of deposition, transfer and sintering is then repeated, building the 3D part. The research focuses on improving the current capabilities of the subsystems within the proof-of-concept prototype tool and the developing computational models along with materials/thermal measurements to understand the nanoscale physics within the microscale selective sintering process.  Previous work has demonstrated fabrication of 3D metal structures with feature sizes of less than 5 microns and aspect ratios of greater than 20 to 1.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The team completed the NSF I-Corps program in December 2021. During the program, the team conducted 100 interviews with owners of successful research commercialization efforts, experts in micro and nanomanufacturing, and experts in the semiconductor industry. After the completion of the I-Corps program, the team attended SPIE Advanced Lithography & Patterning and ASPE engineering conferences to further efforts towards cutting edge technology, current priorities of the semiconductor industry, market understanding and partnership development.

While most of the hypotheses tested were true, the team learned that there are significant hurdles that must be overcome before large entities adopt the technology for high volume manufacturing (HVM). The semiconductor industry has very stringent requirements and standards for throughput and resolution of their products. To compound, the team has spoken to individuals in advanced packaging that continue to affirm that it is a highly risk averse industry that does not like to share its secrets or pain points. Even if a technology fits within the semiconductor industry roadmap, those who attempt to bring emerging technologies to HVM must provide an exceedingly good reason for a switch from existing technology. This reason to adopt μ-SLS may not exist within the next couple of decades as low risk of maintaining old processes dominate decision making for capital equipment purchase. The team believes that the true potential of μ-SLS will be realized in the semiconductor industry, but interest in the technology will develop later rather than soon due to the environment surrounding traditional manufacturing processes. Thus, the team has decided to continue finding customers within the larger companies but is also looking towards building connections with smaller R&D fabs  who would be more willing to take risks in integrating additive manufacturing technologies into their packaging processes. In addition, the team is still actively searching for industries and applications both in and outside of the semiconductor industry that are less risk averse compared to advanced packaging. We are continuing to broaden our perspective on in which sector our technology can be developed and applied and are looking to speak with people in the medical MEMS, and military applications that develop custom ASICs.

Potential customers at equipment vendors also wanted to see more maturity in the current state of the technology before they expressed more interest in helping develop it. The team was informed by an R&D engineer at a tool maker that the prototype needs to show capability of depositing sample structures onto multiple substrates and at an aspect ratio of at least 1:10 before they would consider the technology. Thus, the team will continue to develop the capability to fabricate taller and finer features on sample substrates before continuing to pursue partnerships at companies in the previously mentioned customer segments. This I-Corps experience will help bring the μ-SLS tool a step closer to attracting partnership with a company with mutual interest. The team will continue to meet bi-weekly to discuss applications for other sources of funding to sustain the development of the tool and progress on customer discovery for the technology.

The team sees the technology licensing business model as the most appropriate for the company. It would not make sense for the company to manufacture and assemble machines as the capital required is significant and the volume of products sold would be extremely low. Most parts on the machine, such as the optics and positioning systems can be purchased off the shelf, so that what the company provides is the proprietary knowledge, technique, and software packages required to execute the fabrication process.

 

 


Last Modified: 02/21/2023
Modified by: Michael Cullinan
